conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the motion of the bullets and the carts.
Cart A is moving to the left with speed \( v_1 \).
Cart B is moving to the right with speed \( v_2 \).
The bullets are fired with a speed \( v_0 \) relative to the ground.
Bullets are fired every \( \Delta t_0 \) time interval.
Each bullet hits the target on Cart B when the next bullet is fired.

premise: Cart A is moving to the left with speed \( v_1 \). The bullets are fired with a speed \( v_0 \) relative to the ground.
conclusion: The speed of the bullets relative to Cart A is \( v_0 + v_1 \).

premise: Cart B is moving to the right with speed \( v_2 \). The bullets are fired with a speed \( v_0 \) relative to the ground.
conclusion: The speed of the bullets relative to Cart B is \( v_0 - v_2 \).
The time it takes for a bullet to hit Cart B is the same as the time interval between firing bullets, \( \Delta t_0 \).

premise: The speed of the bullets relative to Cart A is \( v_0 + v_1 \). Bullets are fired every \( \Delta t_0 \) time interval.
conclusion: The distance \( s \) between two adjacent bullets in the air is given by the relative speed of the bullets multiplied by the time interval \( \Delta t_0 \).

premise: The speed of the bullets relative to Cart A is \( v_0 + v_1 \).
conclusion: The relative speed of the bullets with respect to the ground is \( v_0 + v_1 \).

premise: The relative speed of the bullets with respect to the ground is \( v_0 + v_1 \). Bullets are fired every \( \Delta t_0 \) time interval.
conclusion: The distance \( s \) is then: \( s = (v_0 + v_1) \Delta t_0 \).

premise: The distance \( s \) between two adjacent bullets in the air is determined by the speed of the bullets relative to Cart A and the firing interval.
conclusion: The distance \( s \) between two adjacent bullets in the air is given by: \( s = (v_0 + v_1) \Delta t_0 \).
